title: Use US English Spelling
description: Drupal Core uses US English spelling for all source code including comments and names.
examples: {"bad": ["// This function synchronises the data", "$colour = 'red';", "class AnalyserService {}"], "good": ["// This function synchronizes the data", "$color = 'red';", "class AnalyzerService {}"]}
rationale: Consistent spelling across the codebase improves readability and searchability. US English is the standard for Drupal to maintain consistency.
fix_guidance: Use US English spelling in all code, comments, and documentation. Common differences: -ize not -ise, -or not -our, -er not -re.

title: Use Lowercase for CSpell Directives
description: CSpell directives should always use lowercase formatting.
examples: {"bad": ["// CSPELL:IGNORE myword", "// CSpell:Ignore myword", "// cspell:IGNORE myword"], "good": ["// cspell:ignore myword", "// cspell:disable-next-line", "// cspell:enable"]}
rationale: Consistent formatting of CSpell directives ensures they are properly recognized by spell checking tools.
fix_guidance: Always use lowercase for cspell directives: cspell:ignore, cspell:disable, cspell:enable, cspell:disable-next-line.

title: Properly Format CSpell Ignore Lists
description: When ignoring words with CSpell, list them alphabetically with single spaces between words.
examples: {"bad": ["// cspell:ignore zebra apple  banana", "// cspell:ignore banana,apple,zebra", "// cspell:ignore\n// banana apple zebra"], "good": ["// cspell:ignore apple banana zebra", "// cspell:ignore first second third", "// cspell:ignore aaa bbb ccc\n// cspell:ignore ddd eee fff"]}
rationale: Alphabetical ordering and consistent spacing make ignore lists easier to maintain and review.
fix_guidance: List ignored words alphabetically with single spaces. Use multiple lines if the line would exceed reasonable length limits.

title: Use CSpell Disable for Non-English Text
description: Disable spell checking for non-English text using cspell:disable comments.
rationale: Non-English text will trigger false positive spelling errors. Properly marking these sections prevents unnecessary warnings.
fix_guidance: Wrap non-English text with cspell:disable and cspell:enable comments to prevent false spelling errors.

title: Disable Spell Check for Nonsense Strings
description: Use cspell:disable for random strings, tokens, or test data that aren't real words.
rationale: Random strings and tokens aren't meant to be spelled correctly. Disabling spell check for these prevents noise in spell check reports.
fix_guidance: Use cspell:disable-next-line for single lines with random strings. Use cspell:disable/enable blocks for multiple lines.

title: Disable Single Line Spell Checking
description: Use cspell:disable-next-line to disable spell checking for a single line only.
rationale: Single line disabling is more precise and maintains spell checking for surrounding code.
fix_guidance: Use cspell:disable-next-line when only one line needs spell checking disabled. This is cleaner than disable/enable blocks.

title: Disable Multi-Line Spell Checking
description: Use cspell:disable and cspell:enable blocks for multiple lines that need spell checking disabled.
rationale: Block disabling is cleaner and more maintainable than multiple single-line directives for consecutive lines.
fix_guidance: Use cspell:disable/enable blocks when multiple consecutive lines need spell checking disabled.

title: Handle Long Ignore Lists
description: When cspell:ignore lists exceed character limits, split them across multiple lines.
rationale: Long lines are harder to read and may exceed editor or tool limits. Breaking them improves readability.
fix_guidance: Split long cspell:ignore lists across multiple lines, maintaining alphabetical order within each line.

title: Maintain Spelling Consistency
description: Ensure consistent spelling of technical terms and project-specific words throughout the codebase.
rationale: Inconsistent spelling makes code harder to search, maintain, and understand. It can also cause bugs when variables are misspelled.
fix_guidance: Choose one spelling variant (US English for Drupal) and use it consistently. Use search/replace to fix inconsistencies.

title: Spell Technical Terms Correctly
description: Ensure correct spelling of common technical terms and Drupal-specific terminology.
rationale: Misspelled technical terms can cause confusion and make code harder to understand. They may also cause bugs if used as identifiers.
fix_guidance: Double-check spelling of technical terms. Common mistakes: requst→request, responce→response, referer→referrer, loosing→losing.
